DescriptionChanged.old_description:
Implement 'edit <id>' command that opens an issue in the user's preferred editor for modification, allowing editing of title, description, status, labels, and assignee in a structured YAML format.

## Features

### Interactive Editor Mode
- Opens issue in user's preferred editor (respects EDITOR env var)
- Uses structured YAML format in temporary .yaml file for syntax highlighting
- Includes helpful comments explaining field formats and options
- Only creates events for fields that actually change (change detection)
- Supports cancellation by leaving content unchanged or empty

### YAML Format Example


### Programmatic Access Mode
- CLI arguments for automation and AI/script integration
- --no-editor flag to skip interactive editing
- Individual field updates: --title, --description, --status, --assignee
- Label management: --add-label, --remove-label (repeatable)
- Example: git-issue edit 5 --title "New Title" --description "New desc" --status done

### Built-in Issue Template
- Default template for new issues with:
  - Empty title (will be validated as non-empty when saving)
  - Empty description
  - Status: todo
  - Empty labels array
  - Assignee: current user (from git config user.{name,email})

### Validation Rules
- Title: Must be non-empty after trimming whitespace
- Labels: Must be trimmed and contain no internal spaces
- Status: Must be valid enum value (todo, in-progress, done)
- Assignee: Must be valid email format if provided
- Atomic updates: All changes applied or none (transaction-like)

### User Experience
- Clear success feedback showing what changed:
  
- Graceful error handling for editor failures, YAML parsing errors
- Support for concurrent modification detection

### Technical Implementation
- Add DescriptionChanged event to event system
- Add change_description method to Issue model
- Add update_description storage method
- Use serde_yaml for YAML parsing/serialization
- Use edit crate for cross-platform editor launching
- Implement change detection to only create events for actual modifications

This provides both human-friendly interactive editing and automation-friendly programmatic access while maintaining data integrity.
